title: Ed Woodward and Man Utd legend Bryan Robson remember Munich Air Disaster victims in Belgrade
text:

Ed Woodward has led a ceremony in Belgrade as Manchester United remember those who lost their lives in the Munich Air Disaster.

Manchester United take on Partizan Belgrade in the Europa League on Thursday night - only their second match in the city since the tragedy 61 years ago.

United executive vice-chairman was joined by United legends Bryan Robson and Mickey Thomas, who laid down a wreath on the pitch.

A minute's silence was also held to remember the 23 people who were killed in the disaster in 1958.

"It was incredibly important to come here and mark the occasion," Woodward said as he made a short address.

(Image: Manchester United via Getty Imag)

(Image: Manchester United via Getty Imag)

"As soon as the draw happened, our attention turned to wanting to remember those who lost their lives in 1958.

"This was the last place, on this very ground, against Red Star Belgrade, when they played as a team together before they got on that fateful plane to stop over in Munich and tragedy struck.

"So for us as a club, there is a game tonight but for us the trip is also important for remembering those who lost their lives and paying respects, which we have just done by laying the wreath.”

(Image: Manchester United via Getty Imag)

United drew 3-3 with Red Star Belgrade on February 5 1958 to reach the semi-finals of the European Cup.

They set off for Manchester the following day and after stopping to refuel in Munich, the tragedy happened.

Former captain Robson added: "You can feel the emotion. When you have been at the club for as long as we have, you get that history and you have met a lot of the families who have lost people in the Munich Air Disaster.

"I have even heard Bobby Charlton talk about the game when they were over here in 1958. It was supposed to be a great performance by the team and you can sense that when you come into the stadium.”
description: Manchester United drew 3-3 with Red Star Belgrade in 1958, a day before tragedy struck in Munich as they returned home
